#Text=CanadaVOTES : NDP incumbent David
#Text=Christopherson running in Hamilton Centre
#Text=Friday , September 26 , 2008
#Text=On October 14 , 2008 , Canadians will be heading to the polls for the federal election .
#Text=New Democratic Party incumbent David Christopherson is standing for re-election in the riding of Hamilton Centre .
#Text=From 1985-1990 , he served as a Hamilton City Councillor for Ward Four .
#Text=He was elected to Ontario legislature in 1990 , defeating a Liberal cabinet minister .
#Text=Under Bob Rae , Christopherson served as Minister of Correctional Services and Solicitor-General .
#Text=He did not seek re-election to legislature in 2003 , opting to run for mayor of Hamilton .
#Text=Considered a frontrunner , he lost to Larry Di Ianni .
#Text=He returned to politics just months later , changing his focus to federal politics .
#Text=Christopherson beat Liberal cabinet minister Stan Keyes , the incumbent , serving as NDP critic for cities , community infrastructure , labour and steel policy .
#Text=He has served as a member of the House of Commons Standing Committee on Public Accounts , and Deputy Chair of the Parliamentary Steel Caucus .
#Text=Wikinews contacted David Christopherson , to talk about the issues facing Canadians , and what they and their party would do to address them .
#Text=Wikinews is in the process of contacting every candidate , in every riding across the country , no matter their political stripe .
#Text=All interviews are conducted over e-mail , and interviews are published unedited , allowing candidates to impart their full message to our readers , uninterrupted .
#Text=First elected in 2004 , David Christopherson is the only MP to have represented Hamilton Centre , which was created in 2003 from parts of three other ridings .
#Text=Only 38 km ² , small versus other area ridings , it s located on the south side of Hamilton Harbour .

#Text=Alphabetically , Christopherson 's challengers are Anthony Giles ( Libertarian ) , John Livingstone ( Green ) , Lisa Nussey ( Marxist-Leninist ) , Leon O'Connor ( Conservative ) , Ryan Sparrow ( Communist ) , and Helen M. Wilson ( Liberal ) .
#Text=For more information , visit the campaign 's official website , listed below .
#Text=Interview
#Text=Why did you choose to run for office , and why do you wish to continue as an MP ?

#Text=I first ran for office in 1984 because I felt that the government at that time was too focused on its own re-election and on the needs of big corporations , which were already making billions of dollars , and not focusing enough on workers , the poor , and their families .
#Text=I 'm running now , for re-election , for those same reasons .
#Text=The Conservative government , with the full cooperation of the Liberal Official Opposition , has dramatically cut Canada 's ability to respond to the economic downturn .
#Text=They 've pumped millions of dollars into corporate tax cuts ( for oil companies and banks , especially ) and into military spending .
#Text=And they 've refused to invest in infrastructure and communities , in social programs , and in environmental efforts .
#Text=People in Hamilton Centre need good , long-term jobs .
#Text=They need clean air and water .
#Text=They need support for social programs , health care and education .
#Text=They 're not getting any of those things .
#Text=That 's why I 'm running again .
#Text=Are you satisfied with your time as MP ?
#Text=What would be the biggest highlights of the roughly two years since the last election ?
#Text=The biggest disappointment ?
#Text=I am very satisfied with my time as MP , and especially with the accomplishments of the NDP team under Leader Jack Layton .

#Text=We have forced the minority Conservatives and Liberals to adopt strong environmental legislation ; secured money for the clean-up of Randle Reef in Hamilton Harbour ; got the government to reverse cuts to women 's health programs ; and much more .
#Text=My biggest disappointment is that the Liberals , given every chance to fight against this government , chose to do nothing .
#Text=Worse , they either skipped votes or voted with the Conservatives .
#Text=As you campaign around your riding , it 's likely that some issues are mentioned more often by voters , than other issues .
#Text=What would you say are the three hottest topics this election , in your riding ?
#Text=What would you and your party do to address these issues ?
#Text=Only three ?
#Text=That 's hard !
#Text=Jobs is the biggest issue here in Hamilton Centre .
#Text=We 've lost hundreds of good , well-paying industrial jobs and the Conservatives have nothing to offer unemployed workers .
#Text=We want to create new " green collar " jobs through environmental initiatives , such as refurbishing public buildings .
#Text=The environment is mentioned every day , too .

#Text=Hamiltonians are sick of regular smog days throughout the summer , of a polluted Harbour , and of course they 're concerned about global warming and the fact that , under successive Liberal and Conservative governments , Canada is now producing more greenhouse gases than ever .
#Text=The NDP government will introduce a strict cap and trade program to reverse this trend .
#Text=Finally , social programs , including Canada 's national health care program , post-secondary education , and welfare and training programs , are all under threat by the Conservatives .
#Text=The NDP would reinvest in these programs .
#Text=And fourth - can I have a number four ? - Canada 's crumbling infrastructure ( a big word of safe drinking water , dependable transit , etc ) is causing huge problems for Canada 's cities .
#Text=And it means higher property taxes for homeowners .
#Text=The NDP will invest in infrastructure and increase the gas-tax transfer , which we created through the 2006 NDP budget .
#Text=Is there any misconceptions about you , your leader , or your party and platform ?
#Text=Nope !
#Text=There are more ways than ever to get your message out , from the traditional campaign fliers and lawn signs , to new media like websites , Facebook , and YouTube .
#Text=The tried-and-true routes get the message out to the masses much easier , but digital alternatives are much more measurable in how many are seeing or interacting with your campaign .
#Text=What seems to be the most effective , from your experience ?
#Text=Well , obviously there 's room for both .
#Text=Digital communications tools are great - they can be interactive , instantly updated , and used to reach a given audience quickly .
#Text=But in Hamilton Centre , we have many people who ca n't afford Internet services or computers , and many older people who are n't comfortable with technology .
#Text=Traditional methods reach everyone , but are limited in terms of content and can be costly .
#Text=An effective campaign needs to use every available means of communicating with our voters .
